results.content:
CSS and HTML are excellent courses. They are both very in-depthChange I would like to see is the CSS project have pdfs after each segment of project because a lot can change between the videos and sometimes you miss things the instructor says,

 After javascript things get a little less clear.  Some videos refer to segments that seem to have been cut or switched around. For instance Jquery refers to already learned bootstrap and vice versa.

Pros-
•Pdf at the end of each topic for easy reference
•(The instructor) moves  you through more complex websites in an easy to follow way
•Instructor replies quickly to all questions
• All the essential topics for web developing

Cons
• Sometimes too quick to making changes 
•Seems like editing has moved topics around and deleted some things
•

results.content:
I mean, it wasn't a total loss. I liked the challenges, and curriculum is well-thought-out and covers most all I wanted to learn.

But the explanations were really long and rambling and didn't really clarify much about how the different technologies work. For many sections I learned more just browsing through the docs than from the lecture itself.

The delivery/production values were kind of lacking. It seemed like the instructor lacked passion and was like breathing right into the microphone, which get kind of annoying. A lot of manic scrolling and mouse pointer darting to and fro was kind of distracting. A lot of the time it seemed like the instructor didn't really plan out what he was going to say and just decided to wing it, but couldn't quite think of what he wanted to say, so he would just lapse into filler comments like "and with this you can do many different things so let's go ahead and see how we can use this to do many different things," or whatever. 

Not the best course I've taken, but some decent stuff to build on.
results.content_html:
I mean, it wasn't a total loss. I liked the challenges, and curriculum is well-thought-out and covers most all I wanted to learn.

But the explanations were really long and rambling and didn't really clarify much about how the different technologies work. For many sections I learned more just browsing through the docs than from the lecture itself.

The delivery/production values were kind of lacking. It seemed like the instructor lacked passion and was like breathing right into the microphone, which get kind of annoying. A lot of manic scrolling and mouse pointer darting to and fro was kind of distracting. A lot of the time it seemed like the instructor didn't really plan out what he was going to say and just decided to wing it, but couldn't quite think of what he wanted to say, so he would just lapse into filler comments like "and with this you can do many different things so let's go ahead and see how we can use this to do many different things," or whatever.

Not the best course I've taken, but some decent stuff to build on.

results.content: This course was very polished and the teaching was amazing. I really could've liked more tests. We only had proper tests in the first HTML part. After this course I have enough knowledge to do web development (I had 0 experience before) but still I think that introducing tests in later sessions would go a long way in generating the confidence which is required. thank you for this wonderful course!
results.content_html: This course was very polished and the teaching was amazing. I really could've liked more tests. We only had proper tests in the first HTML part. After this course I have enough knowledge to do web development (I had 0 experience before) but still I think that introducing tests in later sessions would go a long way in generating the confidence which is required. thank you for this wonderful course!

results.content:
AWFUL COURSE - DO NOT PURCHASE!!!

This is the worst course I have taken on Udemy without a doubt. Honestly it could probably be considered fraud. The course has "build 12 websites" in its title, yet not a single website is actually created during the course. The course length is allegedly 16.5 hours of instruction time, but this includes a staggering 3.5 hours of pure filler, where "source code" lessons are given arbitrary times yet nothing happens during these videos except for the option to press a download button. Thats 20% of the course time that doesn't actually exist!!

Billed as a course suitable for beginners to Web Development, this is not actually the case. There are many coding elements completely skipped or glossed over entirely, and students are told multiple times throughout the course to go figure things out on their own, which would be fine if the course were free, alas, it is not.

The instructor is absentee, as no questions from students have been answered in the Q&A section. What is the point of having a Q&A section if the instructor ignores it?

The audio is deplorable, with constant lip smacking, saliva swallowing, and breathing sounds loudly audible in each lesson. It is infuriatingly difficult to ignore these sounds and is completely unacceptable for a video-based course. If the instructor can't figure out how to move their microphone away from their mouth without losing clarity, these sounds could also have been edited out post-production quite simply with audio software but this has not been done.

In my honest opinion this course should be removed from Udemy and refunds granted to anyone who was suckered into paying for it. You should be ashamed of yourself Robert.
results.content_html:
AWFUL COURSE - DO NOT PURCHASE!!!

This is the worst course I have taken on Udemy without a doubt. Honestly it could probably be considered fraud. The course has "build 12 websites" in its title, yet not a single website is actually created during the course. The course length is allegedly 16.5 hours of instruction time, but this includes a staggering 3.5 hours of pure filler, where "source code" lessons are given arbitrary times yet nothing happens during these videos except for the option to press a download button. Thats 20% of the course time that doesn't actually exist!!

Billed as a course suitable for beginners to Web Development, this is not actually the case. There are many coding elements completely skipped or glossed over entirely, and students are told multiple times throughout the course to go figure things out on their own, which would be fine if the course were free, alas, it is not.

The instructor is absentee, as no questions from students have been answered in the Q&A section. What is the point of having a Q&A section if the instructor ignores it?

The audio is deplorable, with constant lip smacking, saliva swallowing, and breathing sounds loudly audible in each lesson. It is infuriatingly difficult to ignore these sounds and is completely unacceptable for a video-based course. If the instructor can't figure out how to move their microphone away from their mouth without losing clarity, these sounds could also have been edited out post-production quite simply with audio software but this has not been done.

In my honest opinion this course should be removed from Udemy and refunds granted to anyone who was suckered into paying for it. You should be ashamed of yourself Robert.

results.content: The instructor was clear and the content flow was logical and very relevant. As I advanced through the course I could see how the previous lessons could be applied to current one I was studying at the time. Thank you Udemy and keep up the good work Mr. Adams.

results.content:
The complete trash. You didn't even show how to apply JavaScrip, php and other things in practice, you started jQuery section and used bootstrap there which was not covered yet. 
I suggest that you prepare better before recording lessons and make them more applicable to building real websites. This should not be some 5-10 minutes overview lessons. 
And please stop always telling "let's go ahead and", it's really annoying.
So, I repeat that this course is a complete rubbish and waste of money.

results.content: This course is excellent for a new developer or on e with some experience. It shows various technologies that are crucial for a resume today and provides resources for a deeper independent exploration of the topics.The instructor is excellent, with his knowledge, it is nice to hear the thought process of a developer design and troubleshoot issues.  I highly recommend this for anyone starting out to learn the foundation for these areas of development. I will be looking for other courses he has provided Udemy for purchase next...

results.content: Course is fine up until the JavaScript section, but after that it's a mess. The instructor constantly refers to bootstrap before bootstrap is taught. The PHP section is full of errors and does not instruct the students how to set up for PHP and the instructor makes a ton of syntax errors throughout the course. I understand the need to point out common errors, but you have to remember most people have no idea of the syntax going in, so its just confusing.

The PHP section is full of errors and does not instruct the students how to set up for PHP and the instructor makes a ton of syntax errors throughout the course. I understand the need to point out common errors, but you have to remember most people have no idea of the syntax going in, so its just confusing.

results.content:
He goes to fast with his typing something in and immediately jumping back to a new screen so the student has no idea what he did. Plus the new text typed in is frequently at the bottom of the page obscured by the progress bar.
He should be teaching the student, not showing how fast he is and what he knows.

results.content: HTML and CSS sections are good, it is easy to follow and actually start seriously playing with it. Afterwards it becomes harder. The instructor assumes too much about your previous knowledge and contextualises too little. Further on, it gets more confusing when he uses concepts of sections 6 to explain section 5... Overall it is a consistent effort and you do get the big picture, but maybe the concept of all-languages-in-one-compact-course is just too ambitious in order to  actually work for novices like me.

The instructor assumes too much about your previous knowledge and contextualises too little. Further on, it gets more confusing when he uses concepts of sections 6 to explain section 5... Overall it is a consistent effort and you do get the big picture, but maybe the concept of all-languages-in-one-compact-course is just too ambitious in order to actually work for novices like me.

results.content:
I spent a few days going through this training: it is reeeealy outdated, I do not remember paying for it but still is a waste of our precious time - it should be either removed or hiddend and updated and then made available to clients again.
Instructor is ok and general quality of audio and video - some exercises are too long and sometimes the instructor is actually also looking for a solution himself, which is not that bad but still a waste of time. He talks slowly but I think that's good as you can always speed up with the 1.5 / 2 x function in udemy if you prefer to have it moving faster.
Apologies to Robert, which is certainly a good instructor and person, hopefully I was not too direct, anyway that is what I actually think.
results.content_html:

results.content: I find that the instructor is very clear and very calm while explaining. Just the type of person you need when you want to learn something new. I also like the fact that the course covers a number of languages and that it is a full beginner to expert kind of course and also the fact the it is completely free. I'm really excited about this course and I'm going to stick with it.  I would like to thank Mr. Adams for making this happen and let everyone know that if you want to develop webpages this is the man you should listen to. Looking for a complete course? Search no more!
